Well, I'll talk about the Bodrock chicks because that's what I have. I'll tell you why we've chosen them. What other breeds we've had? At the end of the video, we're going to be announcing who wins, what falls from the sky. Hello, Mr. Rooster. Hopefully it's not too noisy in here for you can hear me. So the couple of breeds we've had, we've had Americanas, however you want to pronounce them, Easter egg layers. These little dinosaurs are eating me alive and here, trying to make this quick. They were nice, pretty neat to have green and blue eggs. But then on the other hand, they didn't lay very well. We've had the White Rocks. They've been a good breed, but they're not very hardy in the winter time. We've got the Bodrocks. This is our third time raising them. They've been eating alive by the Bodrocks, but they're a very hardy breed. They do really well in the winter for us and they're supposedly a dual-purpose breed. Why I say supposedly is we've never raised them for meat. This summer we will be, so stay tuned and subscribe to the channel. We'll keep you up to date. We're going to be raising some Cornish Cross and the Bodrock side-by-side. We'll be doing a comparison to see how, I know they'll take longer, but food, feed comparison and taste and all that good stuff throughout the season. But, I mean, they are eating me alive, but besides that, these little T-Rexes, they're very darsal and friendly. I don't know if you believe that, but they are. The rooster we have here. Say hello, Mr. Rooster. I mean, I can go up and pet him and pick him up just fine. Right, Mr. Rooster? The chicks are very friendly and darsal. They're good if they have the kids around. They do scratch and pack. I think guys, we have ours out on pasture eating bugs and stuff. So they get a little bit more wildly because they're used to scratching the grass, getting bugs and all that good stuff. So they search for their food and we've kind of raised them that way and we're looking for a chicken that does that. Whoa! I told you they were friendly. What's up? See, it's kind of like a pancake, baby. One of the reasons why we like them is for pasture. They'll eat the bugs, the grubs, all the good stuff. And the other part is, if you have them out and you want to have them free-range by your house, they'll eat the ticks on you for you. I don't want to get... There we go. Just don't peck my face. Say, hey, look, camera. Yeah, so they are very friendly, as you can see. She's jumped up here on her own. They'll eat your ticks around the house, fleas, all the good bugs, grubs from your lawn. Keep them out of your garden. I mean, they're just entertaining. Look at that. Would a dog do that to you? It's kind of almost like a goat. I got a parrot for a chicken who lays me eggs. Yeah, I'm looking at you. Don't get too close. That's more friendly than that. There's a chicken on my head. Hey. Okay, how do you pull out of here? Why would you not want to have chickens? Look at all these other things we can do. So we really like the breed. They're friendly, as you can see. They lay great eggs. Now that it's springtime again, early springtime, we have 12 layers and we're getting between 10 and 12 eggs a day. And they've just started picking up in their laying season. We're going to be picking up some Icelandic chicks this weekend. We're going to vlog that trip for you and take you along in the adventure. And we'll let you meet the lady who has these chickens. She's a really good friend of ours. Some of you guys might already know her. But go ahead and look up Icelandic chicks on Google. And then leave in the comments below what you think. Have you ever heard of them? What kind of chickens do you raise? Would you like to raise Icelandic chicks? I'd love to hear in the comments. So for a wrap-up on the question, what kind of chickens should I raise? Raise a chicken that you like, that you think is pretty, and that serves the purpose of what you and your family are looking for. And I wanted to congratulate our Florida's Garden for winning What Falls from the Sky. Go ahead and contact us by our email. If you go to our YouTube channel and click on About Us, you'll see our email address there. Go ahead and email us with your shipping information, and we'll send it out. And if we don't hear from you by April 14th, we will be drawing another winner. So make sure you email us, and we're looking forward to sending that book out. And we'll see you right back here tomorrow. See you guys later.
